I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  This research and development technical assistance (TA)1 will study the rationale for the 
development  of  a  sustainable  fuel  partnership  (the  Partnership)  in  Asia.  The  proposed 
partnership will be implemented as part of the new Sustainable Transport Initiative of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB),2 which aims to develop a pipeline of sustainable transport projects 
across Asia and the Pacific. The partnership will seek to bring together a number of different 
stakeholders, including intergovernmental organizations, national and local governments, civil 
society, think tanks, and funding organizations, with the goal of helping developing member 
countries (DMCs) better manage their future demand for oil. This, in turn, can help contribute to 
energy security and stability in the region. 
 
2.  A common understanding of the term "energy security" is maintaining necessary access 
to energy resources without risking a state’s current and future survival. The world has entered 
into a vicious cycle in which the need to secure energy supplies to fuel economic growth is 
motivating  countries  to  more  aggressively  secure  their  interests  in  energy  resources  and 
supplies, thereby elevating political tensions.  
 
3.  To help improve energy security in the region, this TA will explore an innovative idea—to 
treat energy security as a public good that can be valued and translated into cash flow, thereby 
helping  to  correct  market  deficiencies.  More  specifically,  it  will  explore  the  feasibility  of 
establishing  a  market-based  mechanism  to  monetize  the  contribution  of  oil  consumption 
management measures to energy security.  
 
4.  Although all fossil fuels are highly relevant from the perspective of energy security and 
economic growth, the initial focus will be on oil, for two reasons. First, unlike natural gas and 
coal—which are largely traded regionally—oil is traded globally, and with high liquidity. This 
means that if one country avoids consuming a barrel of oil, the impact on global supply-demand 
fundamentals is roughly equivalent to an equal reduction elsewhere in the world. Second, the 
estimated reserves of oil are far smaller than are reserves of natural gas or coal,3 and therefore 
securing oil is the primary energy security concern of most nations at present.4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
A.  Oil Consumption Trends and Risks  
 
5.  In response to expected high rates of economic growth, oil demand in Asia and the 
Pacific is projected to increase significantly. According to the International Energy Agency (IEA), 
developing Asian economies are expected to account for over 70% of the total world increase in 
oil use between 2007 and 2030,5 significantly impacting global oil demand. The United States 
Energy Information Administration (EIA) projects that the Asia and Pacific region6 will overtake 
North America as the largest liquids-consuming region by as early as 2010.7

6.  Contributing to this situation, the majority of cities in Asia and the Pacific are following 
the past trend in many developed countries by becoming increasingly dependent on resource-
intensive private transportation. Around three-quarters of the world’s incremental oil demand is 
projected to come from the transportation sector (footnote 5), with a large proportion of this due 
to the rapid increase in vehicle ownership in Asia. Given a "business-as-usual" (BAU) scenario, 
the total number of personal vehicles in the People's Republic of China and India combined 
could rise from 19 million in 2005 to 215 million by 2030.8 EIA projects that developing Asian 
economies will consume approximately 34.5% of the world’s transportation liquids in 2030, up 
from 12.6% in 2005 (footnote 7). 
 
7.  Such a heavy dependence on fossil fuels, and especially oil, exposes countries to price 
and  supply  fluctuations  that  can  undermine  their  economic  stability.  The  lack  of  a  readily 
available substitute for oil at the scale required results in very low price elasticity. Small supply 
disruptions can consequently lead to large changes in price. Oil prices have already proven to 
be highly volatile. The price of crude oil climbed from $25 per barrel in 2002 to above $60 per 
barrel in early 2007 and peaked at over $140 in July 2008. Although prices have now declined 
to around $60–$70 per barrel, primarily due to the global economic downturn, the long-term rise 
in demand dictates that there will be sustained upward pressure on oil prices, as well as short-
term price volatility.  
 
B.  Vulnerabilities of the Asia and Pacific Region 
 
8.  The Asia and Pacific region is particularly vulnerable to price shocks, as the majority of 
its countries are net oil importers with high oil intensity (i.e., oil consumed per unit of gross 
domestic product). The region produces a mere 9% of the world’s crude oil supply, while 
consuming about 26%.9 The rise in oil prices has affected the fiscal standing of countries that 
import substantial quantities of oil and offer subsidies to consumers. Such countries are less 
able to weather the financial turmoil wrought by higher oil-import costs.  
 
9.  Oil price spikes also have far-reaching effects on livelihoods. By increasing the costs of 
fertilizers,  food  processing,  and  transport  of  goods,  rising  oil  prices  in  2007–2008  caused 
various commodity prices to increase. In turn, surging staple crop prices across Asia sparked 
fears of a global food crisis and posed the risk of social unrest. The poor, who already spend a 
significant portion of their revenue on food and fuel, are the most affected by such events.  
 
10.  Oil-exporting countries are also exposed to risk. According to a recent report published 
by Chatham House, if the economies of oil-exporting countries "are to continue to grow and 
avoid long-term decline, oil tax revenues and foreign exchange earnings from hydrocarbon 
exports will need to be replaced by developing the non-hydrocarbon economy."10 Thus, it is of 
great concern to see oil-producing countries pressured into boosting supply when their reserves 
are known and finite. More stable and predictable oil prices associated with more balanced 
demand (and greater price elasticity) would help facilitate a gradual transition. The price spikes 
of the kind experienced in 2008 only serve to raise geopolitical tensions.

11.  Market  incentives,  appropriate  public  policies,  and  new  technologies,  along  with 
international efforts to manage fossil fuel demand on an equitable and sensible basis, will 
enable the world to experience a more gradual—and peaceful—transition.  These efforts would 
in  turn  contribute  to  more  sustainable  global  economic  growth,  regional  stability,  and 
environmental integrity.    
 
C.  Proposed Mechanism 
 
12.  This TA will explore a new market scheme to address the challenges discussed above. 
By focusing on Asia, where the largest growth in oil consumption is expected, the market could 
contribute to a significant diversion from BAU consumption growth patterns and enhance oil 
price elasticity. More specifically, the TA will explore the creation of a new commodity—fuel 
security credits (FSCs)—that would monetize the contribution of oil consumption management 
measures to energy security. Through trading of this new commodity, DMCs could access 
additional funds to implement alternative policies, technologies, systems, and fuels that would 
otherwise not be financially attractive. Large oil consumers will reap savings from more stable 
oil prices if the market mechanism is effective, and will thus be willing to purchase FSCs.  
 
13.  In exploring how to create a market for FSCs, the TA will look closely at past successful 
initiatives. The market concept itself is not a new one. It builds on the fundamentals and 
experience of trading public goods, such as the reduction of local air pollutants and greenhouse 
gases (GHGs), "green certificates" for renewable electricity, and "white certificates" for energy 
efficiency improvements. One unique feature of the proposed fuel security market is that it will 
focus on governments as agents of change. This is in contrast to the carbon market, which 
applies a project-based approach, or green certificates (in the United States and Australia), 
which  are  centered  on  utilities.  To  develop  a  proposed  structure  for  the  market,  multiple 
dialogues  will  be  held  under  this  TA  with  (i)  national  governments,  which  set  regulatory 
frameworks such as building codes and national fuel policies; and (ii) local governments, which 
make key decisions on energy-transport infrastructure development and management. 
 
14.  The partnership will also consider the adoption of voluntary "smart targets," which will 
involve setting quantitative goals to reduce oil intensity. However, FSCs may initially be traded 
over the counter in the absence of any voluntary or mandatory framework. For example, the first 
carbon offset trade was in 1989, well before the Kyoto Protocol defined the Clean Development 
Mechanism as a supplementary compliance mechanism in 1997.  
 
15.  The initiative will also have significant additional benefits (or so-called "co-benefits"), 
such  as  GHG  reduction  and  improved  local  air  quality.  These  will  be  secondary  benefits, 
however.  The  proposed  market  does  not  seek  to  replicate  or  replace  the  carbon  market. 
Instead,  by  creating  a  different  public  good—energy  security—this  market  could  provide 
additional income to projects.11  
    
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
16.  The eventual impact of the TA will be to contribute to energy security, regional stability, 
and environmental integrity by better managing the future demand for oil in DMCs. The outcome 
                                                 
11 For instance, a clean energy project could earn both FSCs for its contribution to enhance energy security as well 
as carbon credits for helping to address climate change by cutting GHG emissions.

4   
will be an assessment of the rationale and a detailed concept for the formation of a sustainable 
fuel partnership in Asia. The partnership will bring together a number of different stakeholders 
for  the  purpose  of  establishing  a  new  market  mechanism  to  monetize  the  value  of  oil 
consumption management. This mechanism will help create an incentive for national and local 
governments (among others) to promote alternative policies, technologies, systems, and fuels. 
The TA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
17.  The TA will be implemented over 2 years and will involve developing a major study and 
two proposals. The main output will be a study that assesses the importance and rationale for 
creating  a  new  market  mechanism  that  will  provide  an  incentive  for  national  and  local 
governments to pursue sustainable energy-transport infrastructure that is less dependent on oil. 
The  study  will  assess  the  potential  savings  in  oil  consumption  that  could  result  from 
implementing various policy and technology options across DMCs. It will then model the impact 
on national government budgets and the macroeconomic impacts for ADB’s developed and 
developing member countries that are major oil importers. It will also analyze the potential 
global oil price impacts of implementing different measures compared to projections based on a 
BAU scenario. This study is proposed to be jointly implemented through a partnership between 
key institutions with expertise on energy (IEA) and transport (Oxford University’s Environmental 
Change Institute), as well as finance and regional cooperation (ADB and the ADB Institute). 
Appendix 4 shows the proposed outline of the study. 
 
18.  In addition, the TA will develop a proposal for a pilot scheme that will demonstrate the 
effect of this new market mechanism in stimulating new project development. The pilot will take 
the form of a trust fund that will provide financing to assist selected governments (national or 
local)  to  implement  various  energy  saving  measures.  Among  other  elements  outlined  in 
Appendix  1,  the  proposal  will  include  principles  to  prevent  the  adoption  of  policies  and 
technologies that increase local air pollutants and GHG emissions, as well as to safeguard 
against promoting fuels from feedstock that directly compete with food crops. Development of 
the proposal will involve conducting a series of workshops to consult with various government 
agencies and expert institutions on the optimum approach to implementing a pilot scheme.  
 
19.  Finally, the TA will develop a proposal that will describe how to establish and administer 
a market scheme for FSCs. It will incorporate lessons from similar market-based initiatives, 
including the existing renewable energy regulatory infrastructure that is well established in the 
United States for power markets, and the global GHG emission trading scheme functioning in 
Europe, Japan, DMCs, and other markets. The proposal will also explore the possibility of 
voluntary "smart targets" being adopted by participating countries and cities. It will likely be 
jointly  developed  with  intergovernmental  bodies,  such  as  the  Asia-Pacific  Economic 
Cooperation  and  the  Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations,  and/or  existing  multilateral 
partnerships such as the Asia-Pacific Partnership on Clean Development and Climate.12   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
20.  The total amount of the TA is estimated at $1,250,000. ADB will finance the equivalent of 
$950,000 on a grant basis by its TA funding program (Technical Assistance Special Fund-other

accelerate the development and deployment of clean energy technologies by major developed and developing 
nations.

sources). The equivalent of $300,000 will be financed as a grant from the Government of 
Austria, to be administered by ADB.13 The funds will support equipment;14 trainings, seminars, 
and workshops; publications and information services; fees and remuneration for international 
and national consultants and technical experts; miscellaneous administration and support costs; 
and consultants and ADB resource staff members who participate in country programming and 
project missions. The detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
21.  ADB, as the Executing Agency, is expected to implement the TA through its Sustainable 
Infrastructure Division of the Regional and Sustainable Development Department. It will be 
implemented in close collaboration with relevant internal departments and external partners. 
Within ADB, the TA under the Sustainable Transport Initiative will maximize synergies with other 
ongoing  initiatives  and  programs  that  promote  clean  energy  projects,  such  as  the  Energy 
Efficiency Initiative, Carbon Market Initiative, and the Cities Development Initiative for Asia.15 It 
will also work closely with other donor-led initiatives.   
 
22.  To date, no specific DMC has been identified in whose territory any specific activity of 
the TA will be undertaken; however, any activity funded by this TA will only commence in a 
particular DMC after ADB has received a no-objection in writing from the government of the 
DMC.  
 
23.  The TA will begin in September 2009 and will be carried out over a 24-month period, 
concluding in August 2011. Individual international experts (28 person-months) and national 
consultants (28 person-months) will be engaged intermittently over the implementation period 
under the direct supervision of the Sustainable Infrastructure Division. In addition, $414,000 has 
been budgeted to recruit international firms (for 21 person-months) on a fixed-budget-selection 
basis.  These  firms  will  be  selected  after  submission  of  biodata  technical  proposals.  It  is 
envisaged that the firms’ expertise will include energy economics, urban and transport planning, 
and  market  mechanisms.  The  outline  terms  of  reference  are  provided  in  Appendix  3.  All 
consultants will be recruited in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2007, as amended from time to time).   
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Government of Austria; and (ii) ADB providing the balance not 
exceeding the equivalent of $950,000 on a grant basis, for the Sustainable Fuel Partnership 
Study: Exploring an Innovative Market Scheme to Advance Sustainable Transport and Fuel 
Security, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS  
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) and its partners will undertake a study and develop 
targeted proposals as part of the initial phase of forming a sustainable fuel partnership in Asia 
and the Pacific. The partnership will seek to bring together a number of different stakeholders, 
including intergovernmental organizations, national and local governments, civil society, think 
tanks, and funding organizations, with the goal of helping developing member countries better 
manage their future demand for oil, thereby contributing to energy security and stability in the 
region.  
 
2.  The technical assistance (TA) will be implemented by the Regional and Sustainable 
Development  Department’s  Sustainable  Infrastructure  Division.  Individual  international  and 
national experts will be engaged intermittently over a 24-month period under the Sustainable 
Infrastructure Division. The senior international consultant will manage the team’s activities and 
oversee and monitor the quality of outputs by firms that may be engaged.  
 
B.  International Consultants (28 person-months) 
 
3.  The senior research associate (16 person-months) will have extensive knowledge and 
experience in economic, policy, technology, and financing issues in the transport and energy 
sector. The senior research associate will undertake specific tasks in support of the three major 
outputs of the TA, as follows: 
 
(i)    prepare a study to assess the impact of and rationale for a regional sustainable 
fuel partnership:  
(a)  coordinate with the partner research institutes (e.g., Asian Development 
Bank  Institute,  International  Energy  Agency,  Oxford  University's 
Environmental  Change  Institute)  to  develop  work  plans  and  monitor 
overall implementation; 
(b)  carry out the study, including assessing the technical and commercial 
potential  of  policy  and  technical  options  and  the  incremental  cost  in 
comparison  to  business-as-usual  choices,  and  then  summarizing  the 
quantity of oil demand that can be reduced against different levels of 
incremental cost; 
(c)  lead the detailed terms of reference development, advertising, screening, 
and selection of firms to carry out energy economics modeling and city 
baseline modeling; and  
(d)  conduct  an  initial  evaluation  of  consultants’  outputs  and  make 
recommendations for necessary action and quality enhancement. 
 
(ii)   develop a proposal for a pilot scheme that will be financed through a trust fund: 
(a)  develop the proposal; 
(b)  lead a series of workshops to consult various government agencies and 
expert  institutions  on  the  optimum  approach  to  implementing  a  pilot 
scheme;   
(c)  conduct  one-on-one  meetings  with  various  organizations  around  the 
region to discuss the details of the scheme; and 
(d)  liaise  closely  with  ADB  staff  to  discuss  possible  procedures  and 
organization arrangements for administering the funding scheme;  this

Appendix 3  11 
 
 
will  include  speaking  with  specialist  nongovernment  organizations, 
institutions, think tanks, and government agencies.  
 
(iii)   develop a proposal for administering a regional market for fuel security credits 
over the long-term:  
(a)  liaise  closely  with  Cities  Development  Initiative  for  Asia  and  regional 
intergovernmental  bodies  (e.g.,  Asia-Pacific  Economic  Cooperation, 
Association of Southeast Asian Nations) to develop the proposal; 
(b)  lead the detailed terms of reference development, advertising, screening, 
and selection of firms to carry out the regulatory framework development; 
(c)  conduct meetings with regional cooperation bodies, such as Asia-Pacific 
Economic Cooperation and Association of Southeast Asian Nations, to 
discuss arrangements to develop a regional market; and  
(d)  meet with national and local government officials to discuss the possibility 
of establishing voluntary "smart targets." 
 
4.  The research associate (12 person-months) will undertake specific tasks in support of 
the three major outputs of the TA, as follows: 
 
(i)    prepare a study to assess the impact of and rationale for a regional sustainable 
fuel partnership: 
 
  (a)  help  coordinate  with  partner  research  institutes  and  consolidate 
interagency comments; 
(b)  provide high-quality, research-based assistance and inputs, backed by 
strong data analysis; this includes reviewing reports identifying policy and 
technology options that can reduce the growth of oil import in Asia and 
the Pacific;  
(c)  write specific sections of the study; and  
(d)  help in the process of advertising, screening, and selecting firms and 
coordinate with selected firms in completing modeling studies.  
 
(ii)   develop a proposal for a pilot scheme that will be financed through a trust fund: 
(a)  conduct research to include in the proposal; 
(b)  develop drafts of sections; 
(c)  prepare  workshop  and  meeting  documents,  and  draft  workshop 
proceedings and minutes of meetings;  
(d)  incorporate comments from partners into draft proposal; and 
(e)  coordinate  internally  and  externally  with  individuals  and  organizations 
concerned. 
 
(iii)   develop a proposal for administering a regional market for fuel security credits 
over the long-term:  
(a)  research  other  similar  market-based  initiatives,  including  the  existing 
renewable energy regulatory infrastructure in the United States for power 
markets,  the  energy  efficiency  scheme  in  Europe,  and  the  global 
greenhouse gas emission trading scheme functioning in Europe, Japan, 
developing member countries, and other markets;    
(b)  coordinate  internally  and  externally  with  individuals  and  organizations 
concerned; and 
(c)  write the proposal based on the outcomes of research and meetings; 
among other things, the proposal will describe how the market will be

12  Appendix 3    
administered  and  the  potential  for  adopting  "smart  targets"  by 
participating countries. 
 
C.  National Consultants (28 person-months) 
 
5.  The national consultants will report to the senior research associate and provide overall 
assistance during TA implementation. They will undertake the following activities: 
 
(i)    provide research-based assistance and inputs; 
(ii)   review literature and draft documents, collect data and information, and conduct 
research and analysis as needed; 
(iii)   prepare notes, briefs, and progress reports; 
(iv)   prepare charts and tables, and check data consistency across each document; 
(v)   assist in preparing workshop and meeting documents and in drafting workshop 
proceedings and minutes of meetings; 
(vi)   provide assistance for the publication of the study and proposals; 
(vii)   organize and maintain project files; 
(viii)  prepare monthly and quarterly technical reports on TA operations for submission 
to management and annual program reports for submission to donor agencies 
through the Office of Cofinancing Operations; and 
(ix)   undertake such other tasks as required by ADB related to fuel security and/or for 
the timely and effective completion of the TA. 
 
D.   Firms (21 person-months) 
 
6.  International  firms  will  be  engaged  to  complete  elements  of  the  TA  deliverables. 
Specifically, the firms are expected to complete the following main tasks, among other possible 
research areas: 
 
(i)    in relation to energy-economic modeling: 
(a)  determine potential global oil price impacts compared to business-as-
usual projections, and 
(b)  model the change in oil price elasticity. 
 
(ii)   in relation to city baseline modeling:  
(a)  in seven to nine pilot cities, develop baseline oil consumption trends for a 
business-as-usual scenario, including required investment costs in new 
infrastructure;   
(b)  for  these  pilot  cities,  develop  alternative  urban  development  and 
transportation  plans  and  associated  investment  costs  based  on  the 
scenarios  developed  above  (scenarios  must  be  feasible  for  selected 
cities);  
(c)  develop  a  methodology  for  how  to  calculate  oil  consumption  savings 
between the business-as-usual and alternative plan scenarios; and 
(d)  estimate reductions in local air pollutants and greenhouse gas emissions.  
 
(iii)   in relation to market regulatory development: 
(a)  building on the research of the international independent consultants (e.g., 
lessons  from  similar  market-based  initiatives),  develop  common 
calculation and monitoring methods in order to commoditize oil savings 
for trading;

Appendix 3  13 
 
 
(b)  describe how the market for fuel security credits will be administered in 
cooperation  with  regional  cooperation  bodies,  such  as  Asia-Pacific 
Economic Cooperation or Association of Southeast Asian Nations; 
(c)  explore  the  possibility  of  adopting  "smart  targets"  by  participating 
countries; and 
(d)  propose  the  potential  for  including  other  fossil  fuel  sources  that  are 
becoming sources of regional and global conflict, such as natural gas and 
coal. 
 
E.  Resource Persons (international and national experts; ADB staff) 
 
7.  The  inputs  of  the  international  resource  persons  may  be  needed  in  several  areas, 
including external expert review and specialized analytical inputs, among others. These will 
include  (i)  review  of  draft  inputs;  (ii)  conduct  of  special  technical  work;  (iii)  facilitation  of 
workshops and seminars; and (iv) other specialized tasks required by the TA implementation 
team. Depending upon the task, and as required by ADB, resource persons will provide inputs 
from their own offices, at ADB headquarters, or undertake missions.

14  Appendix 4    
PROPOSED OUTLINE FOR OUTPUT 1 
 
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY 
 
I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
II.  ENERGY SECURITY AND PRICE ELASTICITY 
  A.  History of Supply Disruptions and Price Spikes 
  B.  Future Supply and Concern for Decline of Reserves 
C.  Geopolitical  Tensions  and  Hidden  Costs  (e.g.,  diplomatic  and  military  costs 
associated with securing supply) 
 
III.  OIL CONSUMPTION TRENDS IN ASIA AND THE PACIFIC 
 
IV.  IMPLICATIONS OF BUSINESS-AS-USUAL DEMAND GROWTH TO THE REGION 
 
V.  METHODOLOGY  
  A.  General Approach 
  B.  Inputs and Assumptions 
 
VI.  OPTIONS FOR OIL DEMAND MANAGEMENT AND SUBSTITUTION (including costs of 
each option) 
  A.  Policy Options 
  B.  Technology Options (including alternative fuels) 
 
VII.  OIL SAVINGS SCENARIO DEVELOPMENT (e.g., different combinations of policy and 
technology options, along with varying levels of implementation, including estimated 
reduction of local air pollutants and greenhouse gases) 
 
VIII.  NATIONAL  SAVINGS  ANALYSES  AND  ITS  EFFECTS  ON  REDUCTION  OF  FUEL 
SUBSIDIES 
 
IX.  MODELING  OF  OVERALL  SAVINGS  ON  GLOBAL  PRICE  DYNAMICS  (including 
change in elasticity) 
  
X.  ESTIMATE  OF  MACROECONOMIC  IMPACTS  FOR  DEVELOPING  MEMBER 
COUNTRIES  AS  WELL  AS  COUNTRIES  THAT  ARE  MEMBERS  OF  THE 
ORGANISATION FOR ECONOMIC CO-OPERATION AND DEVELOPMENT AND ARE 
LARGE IMPORTERS 
 
XI.  CASE STUDIES 
  A.  Baseline Oil Consumption Trends for Pilot Cities (business-as-usual) 
  B.  Alternative Urban Development and Transportation Plans  
  C.  Oil Consumption Savings (between business-as-usual and alternative plans) 
  D.  Reduction of Local Air Pollutants and Greenhouse Gas Emissions 
 
XII.  CONCLUSION
